text:
Super Chat: "You should play the DMC reboot! Only Hardcore DMC fans will agree!"

Hahaha... BLASPHEMY.  But seriously, the people behind DmC: Devil May Cry tried to do everything in their power to insult and dunk the original fans, helping to flame a never ending toxic loop between old fans, reboot fans, and the DmC devs themselves. It was an embarrassing and immature clown show led by the devs - a show that tried to kill a great series with a mediocre reboot. So no, we hardcore fans don't agree. If Gura plays it, that's fine. I won't berate her for that and I'm sure most others will behave too. But I could go on without that playthrough ever happening. It's just a pile of sour memories anyways.

Once again, congrats on finishing this amazing game, Gura!
That day was so damn perfect, from your angelic singing, to Thumbnail and them to finally beating Vergil's ass with ease!
You've ROCKED your way into the world of Gamers, like a Pro, I only wish you to nurture that skill to its full potential!
It's clear that when you're collected and not afraid of some small details, you strike for the gold when needed and always come out on top!

For the next DMC game, t's up to you to decide, I understand you want to see Nero asap, but story wise, 1st game should be next, there you meet with Trish, also it's older than 3rd and the controls are a bit clunkier, but you'll get used to it faster if you'll play it now, instead after finishing 4th.
The choice is yours, Same!
Will still watch it and love every second of it! ;3

text: Vergil's Yamato canonically IS able to cut space itself (which is how he creates portals) and has a limited control over time.
author: @SKy_the_Thunder

text: ¬†@SKy_the_Thunder¬† Not quite. It doesn't have control over time, unless you count Judgment Cut End's screen freeze to be literal instead of stylistic. Its canonical ability is that it's able to cut/sever/divide/separate literally anything, even on the metaphysical level.
author: @Harril8265

text: ¬†@Harril8265¬† It feels like it has an effect similar to the Geryon fight, but localized (like Ragtime in DMC5). Would also explain Urizen's slow bubbles.
author: @SKy_the_Thunder

text: ¬†@SKy_the_Thunder¬† I always took Urizen's slow bubbles to be a result of him stealing the powers of other Devil Arms for himself. You'll notice Urizen also has the homing beams from Artemis which he also got his hands on (and fused with Lady).
author: @Terralventhe

text: ¬†@Terralventhe¬† I don't remember an existing Devil Arm with time manipulation though. It was mainly associated with Geryon, which is where Dante gained his Quicksilver Style from. He did apparently have an Elder Geryon at his disposal, but V was surprised to see it, since they were supposedly extinct. So either Urizen managed to comb the Demon World for the last remaining one within days after they split (he had the time manipulation in the prologue fight), or it is a recreation by him - similar to the Angelos and V's summons.
author: @SKy_the_Thunder

text:
¬†@SKy_the_Thunder¬† Geryon's Quicksilver style could be considered its Devil Arm, since a Devil Arm is simply a demon submitting and offering its power/soul to the one who forced them to submit.

He also had Artemis' homing beams during the prologue fight, and had enough time to set up a base. Generally speaking we don't know WHAT it was Urizen did, since he managed to gather all manner of things quite quickly after the split. We can assume Urizen had access to Nelo Angelo's knowledge, and therefore the outline of Mundus' forces and arsenal.
author: @Terralventhe

text: ¬†@Terralventhe¬† Fair enough. Last we know about it is that it was in Dante's possession though.
author: @SKy_the_Thunder

text: ¬†@SKy_the_Thunder¬† True but it's confirmed canon by the devs and side materials that the reason Dante doesn't have Devil Arms between games is because his atrocious spending habits (buying $5,000 leather coats that get ruined every outing) and gambling constantly puts him in the red, so he sells off his Devil Arms all the time. So he sold off Artemis, Cerberus, Agni/Rudra, Nevan, et al, after DMC3.
author: @Terralventhe

text: It was confirmed that the devils arm Dante accumulated over his pass mission had been pawn and the only devil arm Dante kept was Cerberus. In the novel, ‚ÄúBefore the Nightmare‚Äù, he fought Barlog using the triple nunchucks, in which was destroyed during the fight.

text:
When DMC3 special edition first came out, I bought it and played it together with my little sister, who I lost now some years ago. At the time, the fun we had laughing at the silly but still cool moments while banging our heads to the soundtrack are some of the best memories of my life.

Gura showing such genuine enjoyment of and appreciation for the game really brings me back. It was very special to me that she played it all the way through and had so much fun.

When she started talking about wanting to be Dante and Vergil's little sister, if broke me down a little, but it was worth it to watch through this blessed stream and series.

Thank you, Gura. You've made a lonely old fool's days a little brighter.

text: I really don't get why people say to skip DMC1. Not even talking about gameplay DMC3 is heavily based on DMC1 in it's storytelling it all revolves around you knowing what's coming next if you don't then the ending doesn't hit the same and you won't get the significance of what happened. Anyone getting into DMC series should start with 1 and play in release order skipping 2 if need be. I play 2 just because I kind of like it in some twisted way it has unique gameplay. Heavily flawed gameplay but unique. A lot of what's in DMC2 laid the groundwork for enhancing the combat system in DMC3 so it's cool to go back and see ideas in their infancy.

text:
I mean she already "skipped" 1 when she started her journey with DMC 5. People like me advocating she do 4 next aren't advocating she never play DMC 1, just that she play 4 first. I'll try to elaborate on my rationale:

I'd personally recommend new players do 1, 3, 4, 5 for the story but if Gura is already off in the ordering then story chronology doesn't really matter anymore. I personally find 4 to be much more fun to play than 1 which - having just replayed it last year -  I don't feel has aged particularly well and I'd even describe it as jank in a few areas. 

DMC 1 is an interesting game from a historical perspective and a very unique experience but it's going to be a shell shock to someone used to 3, 4 and 5's style of polished combat. My personal recommendation to do it last is if she's done 5, 3, then 4 she'll either want to see more of the story or not. If she's fully invested then the motivation to get the story details will let her overlook the many, many rough edges of 1 and the story will be her motivation to complete it.

author: @samuelrodriguez5282

text: ¬†@samuelrodriguez5282¬† It was from that unfortunate era of Japanese publishers thinking "We need to make our games appeal to the West so we can sell Call of Duty numbers". It was developed by Ninja Theory instead of Itsuno's team and proudly chucked everything that people liked about Devil May Cry to make everything overly edgy and what would be called woke today. The plot is laughable, the gameplay pales in comparison to DMC 3 and 4, and despite game journalists' determination to die on a hill for it the game sold poorly enough that people were sure the franchise was dead so it was a damn miracle we got DMC 5 and it's as good as it turned out to be
